Many teachers also teach and model particular #textstructures, such as procedural writing, recounts, haiku poems, compare/contrast essays.
Expository #texttype. Purpose: To provide information. Basic structure: Fact with supporting details.
Persuasive #texttype. Purpose: To prove your point of view. Basic structure: Argument with supporting details.
Narrative #texttype. Purpose: To entertain. Basic organizer: Sequence of events- First, Then, Next, Finally.
Do you explicitly teach the purpose and structure of Narrative, Expository and Persuasive texts? Here's a quick overview of these #textypes:

Exposure to rich, complex #vocabulary can be incidental (e.g. through engaging read-alouds), but it should ALSO be intentional & explicit.

We're back with Food Group #9: Vocabulary! At all grade levels it's important to deeply explore the meaning of words with students.

Just as #wordstudy can be combined with math/science, it is also a great way to promote inquiry and build #criticalthinking skills!
Try combining #wordstudy with #math and #science! (e.g. make hypotheses about how words work, test them, graph results, etc.)

Teaching prefixes and suffixes can unlock tons of words. Check out Pat Cunningham's Nifty Thrifty Fifty! http://t.co/UfkBi9fg
Food Group #8: Spelling & Word Study. We're not talking about memorizing word lists- we're talking about exploring how words are made!
Msg us with q's about #motivation4literacy #conceptsofprint #orallanguage #phonemicawareness #phonics #knowledgebuilding #writingconventions
Learned a new #phonics fact: the letters i, u, v, j don't come at the end of Eng. words! Example: ai-->ay and oi-->oy at the end of words.
Watching kids (esp. #strugglingreaders) blossom as readers and writers because of a #phonics boost is a pretty magical thing.
Understanding #phonics as a tool that helps students unlock reading MEANING is important. It's not one or the other, it's both!
When choosing a #phonics program, bear in mind that there are about 42 sounds in english that students need to know the letter(s) for!
One of my favorite short vowel games is the chair game: http://t.co/BxTuQVs8
Make sure to teach short vowels! They are: /a/ as in "apple", /e/ as in "excellent", /i/ as in "icky", /o/ as in octopus, /u/ as in "up".
Consider a systematic, sequential #phonics program (like Jolly Phonics by @jollylearning) as 1 part of your students' balanced literacy diet
One way to give kids #phonics practice, esp. #strugglingreaders is to play fun games like this: http://t.co/i5BSedci
#Phonics is not about doing boring worksheets. It's about supporting kids ability to read and spell REAL words!
#Phonics is especially important for struggling readers, who are having trouble "cracking the code" of written language without help.
